content.description: Climb the blocky face on great holds staying on the arête or just right of the arête.
content.protection: One bolt and gear to #2 Camalot.
content.location: Scramble up a to a ledge at the base of the climb with the aid of a fixed rope. To the right of Interstate Love Song, climbing the arete.

content.description: Climbs steep face with a difficult crux at the second bolt. There is some debate whether this is 9+ or 10a. It's probably safe to say this is a 10a onsight.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a finger-sized cam (#0.4 Camalot). Anchor is one bolt and fixed nut with chain.
content.location:
Climb the steep face just right of the right-facing dihedral and right of

Flip Ya Lid

. Shares anchor with

Loss of Innocence

.

content.description: Clean face/arete left of corner and section of overhanging rock where the trail comes up. Good, clean, hard rock with fun, thoughtful moves staying close to the arête in the middle of the climb. This climb was established on a rainy day yet the climb stays totally dry, even in a downpour.
content.protection:
5 bolts. Anchor is one bolt and fixed nut with chain, shared with

Something From Nothing

.
content.location: First route you come to when approaching the cliff. It's the furthest right route.

content.description:
Left of

Interstate Love Song

is this projected climb which will probably be abandoned due to hollow rock in key sections of the climb. Listed and described here to avoid confusion and as an explanation of the anchor visible on the face.

In the middle of the steep face are two bolts protecting the start of this climb. You may want to stick clip the second bolt as it is hard to clip. The crux, a long reach, comes at the second bolt. Finish on easier terrain above, using horizontal seams for gear. Harder for short people.
content.location: On the left side of the crag is an east-facing, steep face. This climb ascends the middle of the face. Scramble up a couple of ledges with the aid of a fixed rope to belay from a belay bolt for this climb.

content.description: Begin in the corner by stemming and climb the face above. A good warm-up with good rock.
content.location:
Climbs the face left of the corner between this climb and

Something From Nothing

.

content.description:
The Drunken Lizard. This climb weaves back and forth, like a drunken lizard," challenging your route-finding skills to ascend this at its easiest grade.

Begin by climbing on face features while plugging gear into a vertical crack at the start. Pass the first, and largest roof on the left. Above, negotiate your way through a few more difficult sections and a couple smaller roof features while using a mix of bolts and horizontal seams for protection.

Save a #2 Camalot for the top and be ready for a few heady sections of climbing above gear and/or bolts.
content.protection: Six bolts and double set of cams to #2 Camalot.
content.location:
Located just right of

Charcoal Burger Daydream

on the tall, south-facing face.

content.description:
Down South is a quality line with sustained climbing and some "serious" sections." It goes with all gear but expect to do some good climbing above your gear. May be the best route on the wall and has been highly touted by those who have climbed it.

Shares the same start as

El Lagarto Borracho

before moving right and climbing the vertical crack system splitting the right edge of the face. Tricky gear and thoughtful climbing characterize the first third of the route before well-protected climbing leads to the final crux. Plug in a couple of cams in the last good horizontal before "punching" it on smaller holds and some thoughtful sequences that trend left before the anchor. This section may not be quite 5.11 but it will probably be considered R rated by most.

Expect to employ a wide variety of climbing techniques on this pitch as it stays "on you" the whole time.
content.protection: Medium to large stoppers, a set of cams to #3 Camalot with extras in the tips to thin-hands sizes. Two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Just right of

El Lagarto Borracho

, sharing the same start before moving right.

content.description:
This is the most classic of the climbs in this area and has been described as a "must-do" route that is worth the trip alone, along with

El Lagarto Borracho

.

Climb good face holds with a mix of bolts and cams in horizontal seams, passing through one roof and finishing on beautiful white and red marbled quartzite. The crux is getting over and past the roof halfway up. The crux may differ for individuals depending on height.
content.protection: Eight bolts and gear to #3 Camalot.
content.location: Located on the tall, south-facing face right of the corner and large, chockstone-filled crack.
